background.name: Lodge Berserker

_.special: A symbol of your berserker lodge

entries: You joined one of Rashemen's many berserker lodges and are indoctrinated as one of its valued members. Members consider one another part of an extended family, happily helping their fellows whenever possible. While traditionally, foreigners refer to all Rashemaar warriors as "berserkers," only members of berserker lodges are considered so within Rashemen. Each lodge has its own personality, expressed by their fighting styles and appearance. Lodge are protected by their own telthor, usually of a creature related to the lodge's name. The members of each lodge are grouped into "Fangs," elite fighting forces ready to answer the Iron Lord's call to defend the nation. Initiation rites vary by lodge but invariably require a demonstration of fighting prowess and completion of various tests such as all-night drinking contests or single handed battle against every member of the lodge. Have you joined one of the large, well-known lodges or are you a member of a small lodge few have heard of? Whatever the case, most Rashemaar look to you with respect and admiration.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: Choose two from among {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Survival}

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A symbol of your berserker lodge (examples include a stag horn for the Great Stag Lodge, a web embroidered cloth for the Ettercap Lodge, or a claw necklace for the Snow Tiger Lodge), a gaming set you are proficient in, a set of common clothes, and a belt pouch containing 10 gp.

entries.name: Lodge
entries: While there are many berserker lodges throughout Rashemen, some only numbering a handful of warriors, these are some of the largest and most well known. You can roll on the table below, choose a lodge from the list, or create your own.

rows: Ettercap. This lodge is popular around the Running Rocks and the High Country where climbing skills are useful. As part of their initiations, they are known to subject members to poisons of various creatures. Members often wear cloth embroidered with spider or web motifs.

Goblin. Popular among the more populated regions of Rashemen, this lodge is known for their guerrilla fighting tactics. When going into battle, Goblin Lodge berserkers frequently wear cowls made of leather or fur.

Great Stag. One of the largest lodges, Great Stag members are often the first to charge into battle, forcing their way past their allies to strike at the largest foes. Lodge members commonly carry items carved from deer antlers.

Ice Troll. This lodge is considered one of the toughest, and its members take great pride in their ability to withstand enemy attacks. They toughen their skins using strange elixers crafted by the Old Ones. When entering battle, Ice Troll Lodge members often paint their faces in shades of blue.

Owlbear. This lodge is famous for their love of firewine, feasting, and brawling. Their halls include sturdy-built furniture that can withstand their frequently violent celebrations. Often, its members wear spike studded armor to augment their grappling assaults. Their greatest warriors array themselves in cloaks festooned with owlbear feathers.

Snow Tiger. This small but fearsome lodge is known for their powerful charging attack. Many use claw bracers to great effect while fighting. Their members commonly wear necklaces, bracelets, and charms crafted from the teeth and claws of predators.

White Dragon. One the oldest and largest lodges are famous for their ability to survive the harsh winters of Rashemen. Weapons and armor made from dragon scales, teeth, and claws are carried with reverence by the most veteran members.
Wolf. The members of this popular lodge are skilled at throwing their enemies to the ground. This lodge commonly wears cloaks made of wolf fur.

entries.name: Feature: Recognized Member
entries: As a member of a berserker lodge, most common folks of Rashemen look upon you with reverence. Your presence assures a limited acceptance by the Rashemaar of any foreign companions you travel with. If you come to a community with a hall for your berserker lodge, you and your adventuring companions can expect to receive free food and lodging of a modest standard within the hall

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Members of berserker lodges revel in its warrior culture. Competition with members and other berserker lodges is seen as a way to define status and honor. Though the Rashemi would never support a gladiatorial arena, it is not uncommon for settlements to host regular athletic competitions and brawling matches where participants pummel each other for increased respect and recognition.

rows: I loudly express my opinions for all to hear.
Talking is a waste of time. It is only actions that get things done.
If I am idle for too long, I must find a way to release my aggression.
I can control my anger even under the most difficult circumstances.
I am utterly confident in everything I say and do.
I am fascinated by the customs of people from other lands and pester them to tell me about where they come from.
Feasting. Drinking. Fighting. There are no better things in life.
I love my weapons. There, I said it.
Honor. Without honor we are nothing (Lawful).
Power. The strongest make the rules. It is known. (Evil)
Freedom. We must be free to pursue our own paths. (Chaotic)
Greater Good. Our lodge becomes greater when we help those in need. (Good)
People. Ideals are meaningless words. The people I care about are all that matter. (Neutral)
Glory. Through battle I will earn glory for my lodge and myself. (Any)
My lodge is my family. Nothing is more important than the people of my lodge.
I will be the greatest berserker in all of Rashemen.
The Red Wizards killed someone I hold dear. I will make them pay.
The spirits of the land will be here when we are gone. We must pay them respect
The Witches of Rashemen saved my family. I owe them my life.
A mysterious voice on the wind calls me to a greater purpose. I will make a difference in the lives of all I meet.
I love to drink, feast, and fight, but I don't know when to stop.
If you are not from Rashemen, you cannot be trusted.
I am willing to take risks, even if it puts others in danger.
I cannot forgive any slight and look to punish those who have done so.
The weak are not worth of my time or effort.
I don't need to make a plan, only the weak do.

background.name: Wychlaran
entries: Your arcane or divine prowess marked you as different from those around you. The powerful wise women of your land sought you out to bring you into the fold. You've either spent your years practicing your magical abilities on your own as an Unproven or willingly joined the witches to train and be numbered among their ranks. When you choose this background, work with your DM to determine whether you're a true wychlaran or a durthan, how far through the ranks you progressed, and what kind of experiences you have had.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill History}, plus your choice of two from among {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Insight}, {@skill Medicine}, {@skill Nature}, and {@skill Religion}

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: Herbalism Kit, set of common and fine clothes, a mask, a stone, twig or leaf from a place you consider sacred, and a pouch containing 15 gold pieces.

entries.name: Rank
entries: In the Sisterhood there are different ranks of varying power and responsibility. You had specific responsibilities and experiences based on which rank you are.

rows: Unproven. Those who choose not to become ethrans, or perhaps did not have the inclination or aptitude for further study.
Ethran. A low-ranking initiate, but still bearing the full responsibility and authority of being a witch.
Hathran. Leaders of the sisterhood. They can doo now wrong and their word is law.
Othlor. The wisest and most experienced. Perhaps only a dozen or so individuals exist.
Durthan. A forbidden splinter group who believe in using any means necessary to defeat Rashemen's enemies, including the use of forbidden dark magic.
Former Member. You have left the order either voluntarily or were asked to leave.

entries.name: Spell List
entries: {@i Prerequisite: Spellcasting or Pact Magic class feature}
As a member of the wychlaran, the following spells are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class.

rows: Cantrip
{@spell guidance}, {@spell shashka|rcg}
1st
{@spell cure wounds}, {@spell shield}
2nd
{@spell gust of wind}, {@spell lesser restoration}
3rd
{@spell spirit shroud|tcoe}, {@spell wind wall}
4th
{@spell fire shield}, {@spell moon blade|rcg}
5th
{@spell restore spirit|rcg}

entries.name: Feature: Position of Power
entries: Your association with the Wise Women of Rashemen gives you a certain degree of power outside of your lands. Powerful arcane and divine practitioners will grant you audiences and occasionally some form of aid in exchange for favors in return.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: The magic you wield, the stories the wychlaran raised you on, and the work you did among the people of Rashemen have shaped you into who you are today.

rows: I see omens in every event and action. The gods try to speak to us, we just need to listen.
I blow up at the slightest insult.
I believe that everything worth doing is worth doing right. I can't help it--I'm a perfectionist.
I feel tremendous empathy for all who suffer.
I'm convinced that people are always trying to steal my secrets.
I ask a lot of questions.
I bluntly say what other people are hinting or hiding.
I'm willing to listen to every side of an argument before I make my own judgment.
Tradition. The ancient traditions of worship and sacrifice must be preserved and upheld. (Lawful)
Power. Solitude and contemplation are paths toward mystical or magical power. (Evil
People. I'm committed to the people I care about, not to ideals. (Neutral)
Destiny. Nothing and no one can steer me away from my higher calling. (Any)
Charity. I always try to help those in need, no matter what the personal cost. (Good)
Freedom. Tyrants must not be allowed to oppress the people. (Chaotic)
I will someday get revenge on the corrupt hierarchy who branded me a heretic.
Everything I do is for the common people.
I will do anything to prove myself superior to my hated rival.
I protect those who cannot protect themselves.
Those who stand beside me are those worth dying for.
I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves.
Secretly, I believe that things would be better if I were a tyrant lording over the land.
I am dogmatic in my thoughts and philosophy.
I'd risk too much to uncover a lost bit of knowledge.
I have little respect for anyone who is not a proven warrior.
I'm horribly jealous of anyone who outshines my handiwork. Everywhere I go, I'm surrounded by rivals.
Once someone questions my courage, I never back down no matter how dangerous the situation.

_.special: twig or leaf from a place you consider sacred

feat.name: Inspired Protector
entries: Once per long rest, you can spend 10 minutes working on defensive maneuvers with one ally you've chosen to protect. At the end of the 10 minutes, you gain a limited ability to use a fighter's {@optfeature Protection} and {@optfeature Interception|TCE} fighting styles to protect that ally. You may use each of these fighting styles twice, plus an additional number of times equal to the chosen ally's Charisma modifier (minimum 1).
This ability to protect your ally lasts until the chosen ally is reduced to zero hit points or until you finish a long rest.

feat.name: Lodge Berserker
entries: You met the strict requirements of one of Rashemen's Berserker Lodges. The intense training has improved your abilities in combat.

items: Select one of the Berserker Lodges below and gain that lodge's benefit.
{@i {@b Ettercap Lodge.}} You have advantage on all climbing ability checks. When raging, you have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.
{@i {@b Goblin Lodge.}} When raging, if you hit a creature with a melee attack, you can take the Disengage action as a bonus action.
{@i {@b Great Stag Lodge.}} When raging, if you move at least 10 feet in a straight line before making a melee attack, you have advantage on the attack.
{@i {@b Ice Troll Lodge.}} When raging, your AC increases by 1
{@i {@b Owlbear Lodge.}} When raging and grappling a creature, you automatically deal bludgeoning damage equal to your proficiency bonus at the start of your turn to the grappled creature.

{@i {@b Snow Tiger Lodge.}} When raging, if you move at least 10 feet in a straight line before hitting a target with a melee attack, you deal extra damage equal to three times your proficiency bonus. You must finish a short or long rest before using this feature again. The berserkers of this lodge are known for using claw bracers (page 122) in combat.

{@i {@b White Dragon Lodge.}} You have advantage on all ability checks to move across snow and icy surfaces. When raging, you have advantage on saving throws against cold, and you have resistance against cold damage.

{@i {@b Wolf Lodge.}} When raging, if you hit a target with a melee attack, the target must make a Strength saving throw or be knocked prone. The DC of your saving throw is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier. You may use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all uses of this feature after finishing a short or long rest
When you level up, you may join a new Berserker Lodge. If you do, replace the feature granted by your old lodge with one from the new lodge.

feat.name: Magic Initiate (Wychlaran)
entries: You've learned some of a wychlaran's magic; this magic is heightened while in Rashemen.

items: You learn one cantrip and one 1st-level spell of your choice from the wychlaran spell list. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.
You can cast this feat's 1st-level spell without aspell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can cast it in this way again. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have.

Once per long rest, while in Rashemen, you can cast any 1st-level spell from the wychlaran spelllist. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell. If you are part of a wychlaran's communal binding when you cast this spell, the spell can be cast at 2nd level instead.

feat.name: Rashemi Elemental Summoning
entries: Your connections to the elemental spirits of Rashemen allows you to summon them in your time of need.
When you cast a spell that allows you to summon air or earth elementals, you can choose to summon an {@monster orglash|rcg} or {@monster thomil|rcg} instead.
Any spells, magical effects, or other features that allow you to transform into an elemental can now turn you into an {@monster orglash|rcg} or {@monster thomil|rcg}.

feat.name: Runescarring
entries: You have learned an ancient technique which involves burning down spell scrolls and preparing the ashes into a poultice. The magical ashes are applied to a needle or blade used to tattoo or scar a creature, imbuing them with the ability to cast spells. To do so, you must successfully cast a spell from a spell scroll. Instead of the spell taking effect, you spend the next hour reducing the scroll to ashes and preparing the mixture. You must then spend one hour per spell level applying it to the creature. This process can be considered light activity during a long rest, and you can stop and start as many times as needed to complete it.
Once the tattoo is complete, the bearer can cast the spell once using Constitution as their spellcasting modifier, after which the magic fades.

A complete scar or tattoo that has not been activated can be detected as magical through the detect magic spell and similar means, giving off an aura based on the spell's school of magic. In addition, it can be removed with the dispel magic spell and similar effects

trait.name: Dual Minded
entries: The troll has advantage on saving throws made to resist becoming {@condition charmed}.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The troll has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, hearing or smell.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The troll regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the troll takes acid or fire damage, it regains only 5 hit points at the start of its next turn. The troll only dies if it is hit by an attack that deals 10 or more acid or fire damage while the troll has 0 hit points.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The troll makes five attacks: one with its grab and four with either its bite or claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) piercing damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage if the target is {@condition grappled} by the troll.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Grab
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature not {@condition grappled} by the troll. {@h}The target is {@condition grappled} by the troll (escape {@dc 20}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}. The troll can have up to two creatures {@condition grappled} in this way. When it does, it can no longer make attacks with its claws until it has one or fewer creatures {@condition grappled}.

The hulking frame of a fell troll bears the weight of two giant heads. Each face is twisted, but wears the unmistakable long nose of a troll. These creatures are sometimes referred to as giant two-headed trolls, and an adventurer could be forgiven for mistaking one with an ettin if the only knowledge of the creature they had was: large, and two heads.

The troll's gray-green skin is bulbous and thick; clad in whatever dead things the troll found large enough to offer it relief from the biting insects and chill winds. The long hair-like strips of skin that dangled from their head seemingly never stops moving.

{@b {@i Glacier Trolls.}} A variant of the fell troll exists in regions beyond Rashemen's borders, but it would not be surprising to find one wandering the foothills of the Icerim Mountains. This variant is immune to the effects of fire, making them a uniquely difficult creature to lay low.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The ice dragon can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The ice dragon can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, {@quickref difficult terrain||3} composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the ice dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Underwater Invisibility
entries: The oddly contoured transparent scales of the dragon make it impossible to spot underwater. While fully submerged in water, the dragon is {@condition invisible}.

trait.name: Web Claws
entries: The dragon has webbing between its digits allowing it to swim faster than its size would allow. The dragon has +10 to its swim speed (included above).

Over nine hundred years ago, strife between the durthans and the wychlaran erupted as the secret sect attempted to overthrow the order and take control of Rashemen. Though the durthans were driven out, they left a terrifying legacy at the bottom of Lake Tirulag. In DR 595, durthan sisters seized upon a white dragon egg and laid power magics upon it, transforming the creature in the shell with potent incantations. Knowing their battle with their wychlaran rivals would not be ended in a generation, despite their hopes to the contrary, these visionary
rebels laid the groundwork for a powerful ally to aid their  descendants seizing Rashemen's future.

At the bottom of Lake Tirgulag, the white dragon grew, a mutant unique among its kind, it came to be known as the Ice Dragon. A beast with powerful, icy breath, and scales that make it virtually invisible while under water. The spirit guardians of Rashemen tried to entice heroes below the waves to slay

the beast, but those who dared always failed. For nearly a millennium the Ice Dragon has laid in wait, gathering treasure and power, waiting for a time to finally strike against the wychlaran and their allies. Now that it has reached its full maturity, the Ice Dragon has begun to stir at long last.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d10 + 8}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) cold damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Ice Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales a freezing blast in a 90-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw, taking 72 ({@damage 16d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. If the dragon uses ice breath underwater, creatures in the 90-foot cone must make a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or become {@condition incapacitated}, encased in thick coating of ice on a failed save, or have their speed reduced by half on a successful one; creatures resistant or immune to cold damage do not have their speed reduced. The coating of ice has AC 13 and 18 hit points. A creature trapped in the ice can break free by using an action and succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength check

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The dragon makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The dragon makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The dragon beats its wings. Each creature within 15 ft. of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 22} Dexterity saving throw or take 15 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The dragon can then fly up to half its flying speed.

trait.name: Fast Movement
entries: While not wearing heavy armor, the hagspawn barbarian's speed increases by 10 (included in stats)

trait.name: Fiendish Heritage
entries: Hagspawn are immune to spell effects that only affect humanoids.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the hagspawn can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hagspawn barbarian attacks twice with a melee weapon.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. one
target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d12 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.
Hagspawn are the discarded offspring of a hag. Hated by their mother and disowned by the human population, hagspawn are stoic beings left to survive in a world that treats them as anathema.

{@b {@i Wanderers without a homeland.}} Hagspawn are beings of great loneliness. Some are raised for a short time by their hag mothers, then sent into the world. Others are abandoned at birth; these foundlings are raised by their adoptive parents, yet hags and humans abhor hagspawn, leaving them to move through the world alone.

{@b {@i Strong and resilient.}} Inheriting great strength and a fiendish nature from their hag parentage, hagspawn are physically powerful. They are doughty and tough, having tough skin and tremendous physical resources.

{@b {@i Capable of great deeds.}} Even the humans who despite hagspawn agree on the legendary feats of arms these beings are capable of. Broadminded folk listen to these legends and see immense potential in each hagspawn they encounter. Given a chance to prove themselves, hagspawn are more than capable of being trusted and powerful allies.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: Hornclaw has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Hornclaw makes two attacks: one with its beak and one with its claws.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 4d8 + 9}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 4d6 + 9}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 21}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and Hornclaw can't use its talons on another target
Lord of the Ashenwood, some Rashemi say that the forest belongs to Hornclaw the Gray, an ancient owlbear. If the fabled ice dragon is ruler of the lakes, Hornclaw is ruler of the woodlands.

Hornclaw is an owlbear of epic proportions. His size rivals giants as he lumbers through his territory, all challengers having met their demise. It is unknown how the beast has lived so long, but many believe it was a creature enhanced by the wychlaran long ago. The witches lost control of it, and their magic causes the creature to grow to draconic proportions with lifespan to match.

The legend of Hornclaw the Gray has reached the ears of monster hunters looking for one massive payout. Several parties are assembling crews to journey into the Ashenwood and capture the creature alive to deliver to wealthy benefactors. It is unknown who is funding the expeditions, but rumors with Rashemen point to (as they often do) Thay. Such a thing would not be out of the ordinary, as Thayan Wizards may be able to understand the magic of the wychlaran and how they bestowed such power on the beast.

Those attempting to capture Hornclaw the Gray are in for the fight of their lives. After decades of roaming and dwelling in the Ashenwood, the woodland spirits aid Hornclaw against any that would harm him.

items: While the living spell is sanctified, it has the following traits:

If the living spell would take less than 20 necrotic damage from a single source, it loses 1 hit point instead; or, if the source was a spell, it loses hit points equal to the spell level (a minimum of 1) instead.
If the living spell would take 20 or more necrotic damage from a single source, it becomes Corrupted (see the Corrupted Form trait).
The living spell is immune to radiant damage.
While the living spell is corrupted, it has the following traits:
The living spell loses all its immunities and gains immunity to necrotic damage.

If the living spell would take less than 20 damage from a single source, it loses 1 hit point instead; or, if the source was a spell, it loses hit points equal to the spell level (a minimum of 1) instead.
If the living spell would take 20 or more radiant damage from a single source, it becomes Sanctified (see the Sanctified Form trait)

trait.name: Draining Spirit (Corrupted Form Only)
entries: When a creature moves into a space occupied by the living spell, or the living spell moves into a space occupied by another creature, that creature loses {@dice 1d6} hit points, and the living spell gains 1 hit point. A creature can't take this damage again until the start of their next turn. This trait has no effect on constructs or undead.

trait.name: Healing Spirit (Sanctified Form Only)
entries: When a creature moves into a space occupied by the living spell, or the living spell moves into a space occupied by another creature, that creature restores {@dice 1d6} hit points, and the living spell loses 1 hit point. A creature can't gain this healing again until the start of their next turn. This trait has no effect on constructs or undead.

trait.name: Magical Form
entries: The living spell can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points, except with its Sustain action or Draining Spirit trait. If the living spell is the target of dispel magic or a similar magic, it loses hit points equal to the spell level of the spell cast (a minimum of 1).

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The healing spirit has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Spirit Movement
entries: The living spell can move through other creatures as if they were difficult terrain.

action.name: Sustain (Sanctified Form Only)
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) necrotic damage, and the living spell regains 1 hit point.

Most living spells are the product of experiments by scholarly spellcasters or random occurrences relating to surges in the Weave or other raw magic. No such event was quite as widespread as the Spellplague, and the number of living spells brought into existence as a result is staggering. No longer are they a rare encounter found only stalking the halls of wizard towers and lich's crypts. Such things can be found wandering in and out of the tree lines of any old forest, traversing the night sky, or simply doing what such a spell would do, were it conjured by some master of the art.

Most living spells are arcane in nature, but the divine spells of priests and druids are not exempt from possibility. The healing spirit spell is a particularly likely candidate, due to its penchant to linger after being cast. These spirits are anything but malevolent. They appear like cyclones of vapid sea-green cyclones, simply twirling among the trees and touching those that are injured with their healing magic. For creatures living among the trees, even one of these spirits would be a blessing.

Despite their seemingly altruistic whimsy, they are not immune to the influence of outsiders. Among the Dunwoods of the Great Dale, the fiendish taint has left its scar on the spirits there—corrupting them into a perversion of what they once were. This corruption can occur anywhere that a malignant energy coalesces, and one should be warned about summoning negative energy near them.

trait.name: Air Form
entries: The orglash can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. When a hostile creature is within the orglash's space, they are {@condition blinded} and heavily obscured. The orglash can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Coalescing Chill
entries: The orglash regains 5 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point and is in extreme cold.

trait.name: Fire Susceptibility
entries: If the orglash starts its turn within 5 feet of an open flame that produces heat, it takes 5 fire damage. In addition, whenever the orglash takes fire damage from a spell or attack, it takes an extra 10 fire damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The orglash makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) cold damage.

action.name: Whiteout {@recharge 5}
entries: Each creature in the orglash's space must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 16 ({@damage 3d8 + 3}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the creature also gains a level of {@condition exhaustion}.

action.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: 3/day:

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The orglash's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}). The orglash can cast the following spell, requiring no components:

entries: Otherwise known as ice spirits, these chill cyclones are native to the Rashemen area. They are solitary creatures who inhabit mountain peaks, ice caves, and snow fields. Orglash are attuned to the land of Rashemen, and stalwartly protect it against threats from without, and within.

Despite being a wholly magical being, unlike many other elemental creatures, orglash are native to the material plane. This natural physiology imparts upon it the inability to survive in warm climates. When an orglash is slain, it leaves behind a shard of elemental ice. If the orglash took fire damage in the last minute before it died, the shard melts immediately. A shard of elemental ice can be affixed to a spellcasting focus, allowing the bearer to reroll 1's and 2's on cold damage dealt by spells they cast.

The cold waters of Rashemen hide numerous fey, including the often-lonesome rusalka. These fey spirits are bound to bodies of water, which can range from a small pond, to as large as a river or lake. Typically they are solitary individuals, however, on occasion, a small covey will inhabit a particularly enchanted location.

{@b {@i Seductive Forms.}} Many stories told in Rashemen's berserker lodges suggest rusalka are the spirits of drowned maidens who seduce men to a watery doom. However, the truth is they are genderless fey spirits whose appearance can vary, though its unclear if the rusalka's form changes to suite itself or the desires of the viewer. A number of othlors can attest to meeting rusalka of different genders, but in all cases the observer described an alluring individual

{@b {@i Enchanting Song.}} A rusalka's voice is embude with powerful fey enchantment and they use their bewitching melodies to entice mortals into joining them. Fey scholars suggest the rusalka entrap individuals to assuage a deep loneliness beneath the waters, with goodly fey using their natural magic to imbue their targets with the ability to breathe underwater. This doesn't explain the motivations of evil rusalka who have been known to entice many mortals to a watery grave.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Rusalka's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The rusalka has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Place Bound
entries: Every hour that the rusalka is more than one mile from the body of water to which they are bound, they suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

trait.name: Strength of the Waters
entries: While touching a natural body of water such as a lake, river, or stream, the rusalka has advantage on all Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution checks and saving throws.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: Rusalka can breathe air and water.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The rusalka makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Beguiling Song
entries: The rusalka sings a magical melody targeting a single humanoid or giant it can see within 300 feet that can hear the song. The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} until the song ends. The rusalka must take a bonus action on its subsequent turns to continue singing. It can stop singing at any time. The song ends if the rusalka is {@condition incapacitated}.

While {@condition charmed} by the rusalka, a target is {@condition incapacitated} and ignores the songs of other creatures. If the {@condition charmed} target is more than 5 feet away from the rusalka, the target must move on its turn toward the rusalka by the most direct route, trying to get within 5 feet. It doesn't avoid opportunity attacks, but before moving into damaging terrain, such as lava or a pit, and whenever it takes damage from a source other than the rusalka, the target can repeat the saving throw. A {@condition charmed} target can also repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If the saving throw is successful, the effect ends on it.
A target that successfully saves is immune to this rusalka's song for the next 24 hours.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 12}). It can innately cast the
following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The shatjan has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

bonus.name: Cold Aura
entries: As a bonus action, the shatjan surrounds itself in an aura of frigid cold. Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the shatjan takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) cold damage. The shatjan can dismiss the aura at any time without using an action. The aura ends if the shatjan becomes {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shatjan makes one spear attack and one gore attack.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage or 6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Frost Breath
entries: The shatjan targets a creature within 5 feet with a blast of cold air. The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

Shatjan are fey guardians that watch over their flocks of reindeer in the cold, desolate lands of the North Country. These creatures possess the head of a reindeer atop an athletic human form. A thick dark coat of fur covers their head, shoulders, and most of their forearms, and they prefer to wear clothing fashioned from hides and bark, decorated with simple patterns and symbols.

{@b {@i Nomadic Protectors.}} Shatjans are typically solitary, following reindeer during their annual migration across the cold northern lands, subsisting on the same foods as the herds they care for. In summer, they gather into small clans building small domed shelters crafted from bark and branches. In winter, individuals follow the reindeer resting in ice caves or simple hide shelters.

{@b {@i Warriors of the Cold.}} Shatjan's are closely tied to the land, understanding the need for a balance between prey and predators. They defend their herds from overly aggressive predators when the health of their herd is threatened.

{@b {@i Human Relations.}} Both Nar and Rashemi tribes of the north consider Shatjan to be powerful protectors of the land, treating the fey with respect and deference. Encounters with shatjan are considered good omens by most, and no hunt begins without leaving offerings for any shatjan in the area. Shatjan have been known to trade with humans offering rare vegetable delicacies unavailable in their cold northern lands.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). She can innately cast the
following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The hag has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hag makes three claw attacks. If the first two attacks hit and all three attacks are against the same target, the third claw attack is automatically a critical hit. She can replace the third claw attack with a Shriek.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Shriek {@recharge 5}
entries: The hag releases a terrible, maddening shriek. Any creature within 60 feet of the hag must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) thunder damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.

The shrieking hag is a horrible, spiteful creature. Resembling a tall woman, often decorated with decadent or lavish jewelry or clothing as though it held some position of resplendence in the past. Their skin is yellow-brown, thick and leathery with hands tipped with iron-hard talons. Their long white hair whips about as though trapped in a cold northern wind.

There is nothing a shrieking hag loves more than tricking those of virtue or strong moral conviction, into performing horrible acts unknowingly. These plots are often designed to cause confusion or chaos, drawing attention away from their escapes. When caught, they fly into a screeching rage, trying to cause as much death or destruction as possible in their flight.

{@b {@i Wandering Terrors.}} Shrieking hags like to travel about the mortal world, causing strife before moving on to their next hunting ground. They rarely stay in place, drifting as a breeze across the plains.

{@b {@i Masters of the Wind.}} With their innate spellcasting and their flight, shrieking hags are incredibly hard to pin down. It's said in Rashemen that ill winds carry unseen dangers. The hags like to travel light, with most of their possessions being jewelry or clothing.

{@b {@i Crone Canes.}} Each shrieking hag possesses a staff, cane, or crook that, while they have no need for, is an incredibly personal item that they personally craft and develop over time. For old hags, this item could be densely populated with gems, precious metals, bones, or anything else the hag fancied and collected.

trait.name: Regal Presence
entries: The ape spirit beast has an aura that extends to 120 feet. Beasts within this area cannot be compelled to act against their nature. Beasts in this area will not make aggressive actions against creatures of the ape spirit beast's choosing. Beasts in this area will defend the ape spirit beast with their life, if necessary. Beasts within this area add +3 to their attacks and saving throws.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ape makes two fist attacks.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@dice 1d6 + 3}
+ {@dice 3d12}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 25/50 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@dice 1d6 + 3}{@dice  + 3d12}) bludgeoning damage.

When the spirits of nature feel the need to contact those in the world who listen to their movements, a representative beast will be chosen and enhanced with otherworldly capabilities and transformed into gigantic versions of themselves.

{@b {@i Regents of the Spirit World.}} These gigantic beasts are seen by other creatures in nature as kings and queens, blessed and chosen. Predatory animals will not take aggressive actions against the spirit beast or other beasts while in its presence

{@b {@i Authoritative Representation.}} Nature itself reacts to the moods, thoughts, and whims of a spirit beast. When a spirit beast gets angry, skies darken and thunder ripples. The death of a spirit beast is typically accompanied by a few days of nature grieving.

{@b {@i Wandering Lair.}} After taking a short or long rest in any natural area, nature starts to reconfigure itself to suit the spirit beast. A boar spirit beast might have muddy wallows form, while a mandril spirit beast finds trees change their shape to become more climbable. This lair is typically filled with more beasts of the same type, and many chwingas.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The priest is a 5th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, +5 to hit with spell attacks). The priest has the following cleric spells prepared:

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Mountain spirit folk's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, +5 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Charm Animals and Plants (1/day)
entries: Each beast or plant creature within 30 feet of the priest must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by the cleric for 1 minute or until it takes damage.

trait.name: Daring Athlete
entries: Mountain spirits have advantage on all Dexterity or Strength checks while on steep slopes, sheer edges, or narrow paths or other mountainous or treacherous terrain.

trait.name: Expert Climber
entries: Mountain spirit folk have advantage on all Strength (Athletics) checks made while climbing.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60, one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}({@dice 1d6}) piercing damage.
The spirit folk are a people descended from human and guardian spirit ancestors. They are rare and most often found in the mountains or near riverbeds.

{@b {@i At home in two worlds.}} Spirit folk have a close affinity to the natural environment. As descendents of the guardian spirits of Rashemen, they feel equally at home in the natural world or in the small towns and cities of this region.

{@b {@i Serene and wise.}} Those who encounter spirit folk often remark on their effervescent joy for life. Spirit folk are deeply engaged in life and see themselves as rooted and belonging to the world, not at odds with it. This continent awakens both envy and admiration in those whom they encounter.

{@b {@i Long lived travellers.}} Spirit folk can live up to 400 years. During their long lives, some engage the human world directly, living within communities acting as clerics of local gods or trusted councillors. To avoid becoming too heavily relied upon, most spirit folk only stay in a settlement for the duration of one human generation, then leave to find a new home where they might contribute.

Despite their relative size, these creatures are impressively bulky and carry a dominant air about them. Taer call the mountain regions of northern Faern their home from the Spine of the World all the way east to the Icerim Mountains north of Rashemen. Myths of blue-haired mountain beasts coming down like an avalanche to raid small outposts and villages often refer to the taer, but like all myths, contain a significant portion of creative emphasis. When taer raid villages, they take livestock and supplies—such as blankets, tools, and timber—resources they would not otherwise have access to in the glacial mountain ranges.

Their society comprises familial pods no more than two generations large. Typically, once taer reach the age in which they can bear children, their parents leave to roam the wastes or scavenge gifts that they leave for their young to ensure that the scant resources are allocated to the most promising generation. Each pod typically has at least one adept, a spiritual leader connected to either Auril or in rare cases, Loviatar.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The taer makes two melee weapon attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 2d4}) cold damage.

action.name: Great Club
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

Despite their relative size, these creatures are impressively bulky and carry a dominant air about them. Taer call the mountain regions of northern Faern their home from the Spine of the World all the way east to the Icerim Mountains north of Rashemen. Myths of blue-haired mountain beasts coming down like an avalanche to raid small outposts and villages often refer to the taer, but like all myths, contain a significant portion of creative emphasis. When taer raid villages, they take livestock and supplies—such as blankets, tools, and timber—resources they would not otherwise have access to in the glacial mountain ranges.

Their society comprises familial pods no more than two generations large. Typically, once taer reach the age in which they can bear children, their parents leave to roam the wastes or scavenge gifts that they leave for their young to ensure that the scant resources are allocated to the most promising generation. Each pod typically has at least one adept, a spiritual leader connected to either Auril or in rare cases, Loviatar.

action.name: Frostbite (Cantrip)
entries: One creature the adept can see within 60 feet must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage, and they have disadvantage on the next weapon attack roll they make before the end of their next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The taer makes two melee weapon attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) cold damage.

trait.name: Frostskin
entries: The adepts fur and skin are magically frozen, creating a hard barrier. Their AC can't be less than 16.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The adept's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks). They can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The telthor has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The telthor has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the telthor's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Nature Empathy
entries: The telthor can command beasts, who will always regard the telthor as an ally.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} ({@dice 2d4 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.
Beings that die in defense of nature sometimes leave behind a spiritual echo, a ghostly version of themselves to continue their work.

{@b {@i Feywild Echoes.}} These spirits might resemble beings who lived, but they are more akin to nature using a bit of fey magic to honor their sacrifice. These spirits actually have no memories held by the once-living creature they resemble.
{@b {@i Bound to the Land.}} A telthor cannot travel further than 1 mile away from the location where the living creature it is echoing died.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The thomil can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the thomil doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The elemental deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The thomil makes two slam attack

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} + {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be pushed back 10 ft.

action.name: Engulf
entries: The thomil can choose to engulf a target it hits with a slam attack. The engulfed target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or become melded into the thomil's body. The engulfed target is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has  total cover against attacks and other effects outside the  thomil, and it takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage at the start of each of the thomil's turns. The thomil can only have one target engulfed at a time. If the thomil dies, an engulfed  reature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse using 10 feet of movement, existing {@condition prone}.

Native to the coldest parts of Rashmen, thomil's, also known as rock spirits, are earth elementals that are created or summoned to guard Rashemen against its enemies. They resemble humanoid forms from the waist up but instead of feet they are solid rock and earth. Thomil's waited beneath the earth remaining dormant until they sensed a threat and sprang into action.

The Rashemi people both respect and fear the thomils. Because even though they repel invaders and typically keep their borders safe they also punish those that don't give proper worship to them. Individuals that are greedy and short-sighted eventually find themselves standing face to face with a thomil.
Before any type of mining operation begins, the locals call in a hathran to bless the land and appropriately appease any thomils that may be lying dormant.

vulnerable.note: from weapons made of wood or stone

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The uthraki has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Shapechanger (Werebear)
entries: The uthraki can use its action to polymorph into a Medium or smaller humanoid or beast or back into its true form. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies. Only true seeing or similar magic will reveal the uthraki's true form.

trait.name: Regeneration (Troll)
entries: The uthraki regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn at night. If the uthraki takes damage froma silvered weapon or is illuminated by sunlight, this trait doesn't function at the start of the uthraki's next turn. The uthraki dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The uthraki makes two claw attacks

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target.
{@h}25 ({@damage 5d6 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 50/100 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 7d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

Uthraki are denizens of the forests and foothills surrounding Rashemen. They appear to be large, ape-like creatures clad in white fur with patches of exposed skin in various areas of their body. These nocturnal spirits are keenly aware of their surroundings: as they have eyes evenly spaced around their head in all directions. This trait—as well as their menacing teeth and claws—persist in any form they take with their ability to shapeshift. Uthraki spend much of their time in a  hapeshifted form, as their numbers are being hunted into near extinction by the hathrans.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The vodyanoi has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The vodyanoi can breathe air and water.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vodyanoi makes two claw attacks. If both attacks hit a Medium or smaller target, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}).

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk m} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage + 2 ({@damage 1d4}) cold damage.

action.name: Fish Cloud
entries: When fully submerged in water, a vodyanoi can summon a school of magical fish occupying a 20-foot-radius sphere within 30 feet. The affected area is treated as if under the effect of a fog cloud spell, but the fish can only be dispersed by a strong current. The fish are not real and disappear if caught. The fish cloud persists as long as the vodyanoi maintains concentration as per a spell up to a maximum of 10 minutes.
Fishermen and those working on the waters in Rashemen often give offerings of fish and livestock to local vodyanoi to placate the often cantankerous fey.

{@b {@i Underwater Hermits.}} These taciturn fey always appear as old men with yellow-green straggly hair and similarly colored long beards. Their long skinny arms end in large hands with sharp claw-like nails. These creatures can breathe air and water, but rarely leave their watery homes.

{@b {@i Watery Control.}} Vodyanoi can affect the waters in which they live and can do so to devastating effect when offended. Most villagers have heard stories of disrespectful fisherman drowning beneath the waters, or entire villages being swept away by suddenly surging rivers. However, these moody fey occasionally will trade water bound treasures for goats, cows, or other livestock, and may even shepherd schools of fish near villages that have treated them well.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the berserker can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges After a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the berserker takes damage that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The berserker makes three attacks.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d12 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the berserker can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges After a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the berserker takes damage that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Battle Scarred
entries: When calculating its AC, the berserker can use its Constitution modifier instead of its Dexterity modifier (already included).

trait.name: Indomitable (1/day)
entries: The berserker rerolls a failed saving throw.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The berserker makes three attacks.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

legendary.name: Weapon Attack
entries: The berserker makes a weapon attack

legendary.name: Charge (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The berserker moves up to its speed, then makes an attack with its greataxe.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the berserker can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges After a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the berserker takes damage that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Battle Scarred
entries: When calculating its AC, the berserker can use its Constitution modifier instead of its Dexterity modifier (already included).

trait.name: Indomitable (3/day)
entries: The berserker rerolls a failed saving throw.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The berserker makes three attacks.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

legendary.name: Weapon Attack
entries: The berserker makes a weapon attack

legendary.name: Charge (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The berserker moves up to its speed, then makes an attack with its greataxe.

trait.name: Bonded Casting
entries: When the wychlaran casts the {@spell shield of faith} spell using one of its spell slots, it can choose for the spell to also affect up to two allies within 30 feet. The effect lasts for the duration, with only the wychlaran needing to maintain concentration.

trait.name: Communal Binding (3/day)
entries: Whenever an ally within 30 feet. of the wychlaran makes an attack, damage, or saving throw roll, the wychlaran may choose to add {@dice 1d4} to that roll. The wychlaran can use this ability no more than once per turn.

action.name: Shashkah
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The wychlaran is a 4th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, +5 to hit with spell attacks). It  can cast the following wychlaran spells:

trait.name: Bonded Casting
entries: When the wychlaran casts the {@spell freedom of movement} or {@spell spirit shroud} using one of its spell slots, it can choose for the spell to also affect up to two allies within 30 feet. The effect lasts for the duration, with only the wychlaran needing to maintain concentration.

trait.name: Communal Binding (3/day)
entries: Whenever an ally within 30 feet. of the wychlaran makes an attack, damage, or saving throw roll, the wychlaran may choose to add {@dice 1d4} to that roll. The wychlaran can use this ability no more than once per turn.

trait.name: Unweave (3/day)
entries: The wychlaran can cast {@spell counterspell} and {@spell dispel magic} at its lowest level without using a spell slot or any components. Additionally, if the wychlaran needs to make an ability check as part of targeting a spell of the enchantment or necromancy schools, it can add its proficiency bonus to this ability check.

action.name: Shashkah
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The wychlaran is a 12th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). It  can cast the following wychlaran spells:

trait.name: Bonded Casting
entries: When the wychlaran casts the {@spell freedom of movement}, {@spell spirit shroud}, or {@spell tasha's otherworldly guise|tce} using one of its spell slots, it can choose for the spell to also affect any number of allies within 30 feet. The effect lasts for the duration, with only the wychlaran needing to maintain concentration.

trait.name: Communal Binding (3/day)
entries: Whenever an ally within 30 feet. of the wychlaran makes an attack, damage, or saving throw roll, the wychlaran may choose to add {@dice 1d6} to that roll. The wychlaran can use this ability no more than once per turn.

trait.name: Unweave (3/day)
entries: The wychlaran can cast {@spell counterspell} and {@spell dispel magic} at its lowest level without using a spell slot or any components. Additionally, if the wychlaran needs to make an ability check as part of targeting a spell of the enchantment or necromancy schools, it can add its proficiency bonus to this ability check.

action.name: Shashkah
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The wychlaran is a 18th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 17}, +9 to hit with spell attacks). It  can cast the following wychlaran spells:

spell.name: Moon Blade

m.text: a small candy made with wintergreen oil

entries: You evoke a blazing sword of moonlight into your hand. The moon blade is a simple weapon with which you are proficient. It deals {@damage 3d8} radiant damage on a hit and has the finesse and light properties. The blade deals an additional {@roll 2d8} radiant damage to undead on a hit.

Targets struck by the moon blade have difficulty maintaining or casting spells. Creatures have disadvantage on concentration checks made against damage from the moon blade. Additionally, until the end of the target's next turn, targets must succeed on a saving throw using their spellcasting ability to cast a spell, or their spell fails and has no effect.

spell.name: Placebind

m.text: a drop of water, a plant seed, and an area at least 100 feet in diameter

entries: Over the course of 8 hours, you guide any number of willing creatures in a ceremony that gives them familiarity with the local area. Participants are able to rest or perform other activities during the ceremony, so long as they do not leave the ceremonial circle and as long as you are able to complete a walk along the circle's edge at least once every 2 hours.

Once cast, the effects of the spell allow the participants to use any of their class features or traits that require a specific terrain type, such as a ranger's Favored Terrain or the wychlaran's Place Magic, on the terrain in a 50-mile radius from the spell's casting. The spell's effect encompasses areas above and below ground, but does not extend to other planes of existence.

This spell does not alter the terrain, only the targets' familiarity with it. For example, a ranger with the Favored Terrain of tundra doesn't suddenly find snow in the desert, they simply treat the terrain in the spell's area of effect as favored, regardless of its type. Abilities requiring the presence of specific physical components such as plants or a storm still require those elements.
The familiarity gained through this spell fades when a creature finishes a long rest.

spell.name: Restore Spirit

m.text: firewood, and rare herbs worth at least 500 gp, which the spell consumes

entries: You perform a ceremony that cleanses and restores the target creature's'' spirit. The ceremony removes the following harmful effects:

items: Any effect causing the target to be blinded, charmed, deafened, exhausted, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, or stunned
Any curses
Possession
Any reductions to the target's ability scores
Any effect reducing the target's maximum hit points
Any negative effects suffered as a result of casting or being subjected to a raise dead or resurrection spells.
Any effects suffered as a result of Wychlaran Communal Bonding being broken

spell.name: Scatterspray
entries: You target a collection of at least six small unsecured objects located within one foot of each other. The objects can be no larger an apple and collectively weigh less than 25 pounds. You cause these objects to fly off in all directions. Creatures within 10 feet of the objects must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or they are struck by the flying items. If the items are hard or sharp, such as stones, sling bullets, coins, or similar, struct creatures take {@damage 2d8} points of bludgeoning damage. If the targeted objects are softer, such as eggs or berries, the spell deals half damage and creatures who fall to 0 hit points from the attack are not killed, but are unconscious and stable instead.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@damage 1d8} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Shashkah

m.text: a tuft of black wool, a human hair, and a sword

entries: A sword you are holding is imbued with the power of ancient spirits, guiding you in its use. For the duration, you can use your spellcasting ability instead of Strength or Dexterity for the attack and damage rolls of melee attacks using that weapon. The spell ends if you cast it again or if you are not holding the weapon at the end of your turn.

spell.name: Turn Fiend

m.text: a witch bottle containing salt, an ounce of holy water, and chalk worth 50 gp

entries: You unseal the bottle, and a gaseous mixture fills the air around you. Each fiend of Challenge Rating 1 or lower within range must make a Wisdom saving throw. If the creature fails its saving throw, they are turned for 1 minute or until they take any damage.

A turned creature must spend their turns trying to move as far away from you as they can, and they can't willingly move to a space within 30 feet of you. They also can't take reactions. For their action, they can use only the Dash action or try to escape from an effect that prevents them from moving. If there's nowhere to move, the creature uses the Dodge action.
At the end of its turn, a turned creature can repeat this saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th or 6th level, the Challenge Rating of fiends it can affect increases to 2 or lower. If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th or 8th level, the Challenge Rating increases to 4 or lower. If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 9th level, the Challenge Rating increases to 7 or lower.

spell.name: Vulnerability
entries: You touch a creature and mark it with a curse of vulnerability. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or become cursed. While cursed in this way, the target has disadvantage on saving throws they make to resist your spells.

spell.name: Waterspout

m.text: a piece of grass or seaweed twisted into a coil

entries: You conjure a whirling, cylindrical column of water 10 feet in diameter and 60 feet tall rising up from the ground or a body of water. Creatures within 10 feet of the waterspout must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be sucked into the spout. Creatures in water have disadvantage on the saving throw. Any creature that starts its turn inside the spout takes {@damage 2d6} bludgeoning damage and is grappled by the spout (escape DC equal to your spellcasting DC). Targets are restrained while grappled in this way.
As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the spout up to 30 feet in any direction, provided it stays in contact with the ground or a body of water
